This Saturday, May 6th, the most anticipated day in horse racing will take place at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky in the 149th running of the Kentucky Derby. With that in mind, a vast audience will not only be watching the race but, with online betting legal in several states across the country, a huge amount of first-time bettors will be anxious to take part in one of sports’ great spectacles. Here is a guide on how you can place a wager on Saturday’s event.

How are The Odds Determined?

Each horse will have odds assigned to it based on the likelihood of winning. Remember, in any bet, you earn back your initial investment plus your winnings. For example, if you bet $2 to win on a horse that is a 3-2 favorite, you win back your $2 and $3 for the win to take home a total of $5. In other words, you win $3 for every $2 bet. Last year, the winner, Rich Strike, went off at 80-1 so a bettor won $80 for every $1 bet on Rich Strike.

Types of Bets in HOrse Racing

There are two types of bets in horse racing: straight bets and exotic bets. Straight bets are placed on a single horse to either win, place (2nd) or show (3rd). You can also, which I recommend, bet the same horse across the board. This simply means that you can win if your horse comes in first, second, or third. A $2 across-the-board bet on a horse will cost you $6. If your horse wins the race, you get the money paid out for first, second, and third.

Exotic bets are bets placed on two or more horses to finish in a specific order. The level of difficulty increases with more horses involved but the payouts are higher. In the case of Rich Strike last year, with 80-1 odds to win, an exotic bet hit in that race would pay significantly more than it would had the favorite won the race.

Click here to sign up with TwinSpires and their $400 sign-up Bonus 

Here are examples of Exotic bets: 

Exacta

This is a bet on two horses to finish first and second place and they have to finish in that exact order to win.

Trifecta

In this case, you place a bet on three horses to finish 1st, 2nd, and 3rd, and, once again, they have to finish in the exact order you bet them to win the bet.

Superfecta

Now you are betting on the exact finish of the top four horses in the race. Once again, your odds go up but you have to hit this exactly to win the bet.

Boxing Exotic Bets

You can also decide to ‘box’ your bet in order to increase your odds of winning. A boxed wager pays out regardless of the order you bet the horses but is more expensive because you are paying for all the scenarios. So, you can box four horses in an exacta box and win if any two of the horses finish top-2 in the race.

Early Bettors Beware

One thing to keep in mind, you can certainly wager early but the odds you get for the race are the final odds that close at race time. For example, if you place a wager on Thursday prior to the race on Saturday, your horse might have odds of 26-1. However, by race time, the horse’s odds could have dropped to 4-1 based on betting interest. The 4-1 odds will be the odds you get for the race. I generally wait ten minutes or less before race time before I make my wager. This gives me a good idea of where the ‘smarts’ are putting their money and the opportunity to make a more educated bet. Either way, have fun, do some studying, and don’t bet beyond your means!

item.content:encoded:
With the Kentucky Derby fast approaching, let’s examine another critical element of the race that could help predict the race’s outcome. The Kentucky Derby is a race comprised of 20 horses, double the size of the typical field of ten horses in a specific horse race. With 20 horses vying for space on a crowded track, post position can often dictate the outcome of the derby.

What is Post position?

Post position refers to the starting gate assigned to a horse prior to the race. The positions are given based on a random draw prior to the running of the race. With twenty stalls across the track, things can get crowded. The #1 position is right near the rail. If that horse happens to get right out and hug the rail, the horse will have a shorter ride. Conversely, the 20th position is the furthest away from the rail and that horse may have trouble navigating back towards the middle of the track. Staying outside would result in the longest track to cover in the field.

Overall, the inside positions are more favorable since the distance to the first turn is the quickest and can allow a horse to save energy by hanging on the rail. The outside positions require a horse to exert more energy earlier in the race to get toward the middle of the track and ultimately run a longer race. The odds of a horse winning usually change based on the post position.

Turning $10 into $20,000 sounds too good to be true, and you’d be right if I was talking about sports. I’m talking about Horse Racing, and specifically the Kentucky Derby this weekend.

Know nothing about horses? That’s fine, stick with me here and I’ll explain why.

First, I have a sign-up offer from our partners at Daily Racing Form which will give you $10 free for just signing up. No need to deposit anything! (Offer expired, click here for this year’s best offers.)

Second, I am going to give you the exact wagers that have the best chance to turn that free $10 into $20k that you can take home.

Still skeptical? Let me explain what makes Horse Racing different from sports betting and why I love the ponies and you should too.

Why you should bet on Horse Racing

In horse racing, all wagers are done in a pool. The track and government take a fixed cut out of this pool, and the rest are divided up among the winners of the bet. On a normal race day, the payout is typically fairly inline with the odds. But during a big race day, the general public will throw in a lot of money on favorites as a “sure thing”. This massively inflates the pool and allows smart bettors to pocket that money.

See where I am going with this?

The Kentucky Derby is the biggest day in horse racing, which also makes it the biggest pool available. Typically more than $200,000,000 is wagered with the vast majority of that by spectators and casual bettors just wanting to turn $2 into $5 by piling on the favorite.

But the favorite has only won 5 out of the last 34 derbies. That’s equivalent to 8-1 odds, but the favorites are always listed as 3-1 or even 3-2. Clearly there isn’t any money to be made taking the favorite, but the public is going to do it anyway every single time.

That’s a good thing though, because that means the pool is bigger for the sharp bettors to cash in big.

This is why you can turn $10 into $20,000 during the Kentucky Derby and why I love the ponies so much!

I want you to get a taste of the action, especially with our friends at DRF giving you a free $10 to get started with for just signing up! (Click here to get that offer)

My $10 Superfecta Strategy

In the main event, Race 12 of the Kentucky Derby, I really like the following horses:

#9 – Tiz the Bomb
#15 – White Abarrio
#16 – Cyber Knife
#6 – Messier

I really like #9 to win, #15 and #16 to be second or third, and #6 to be fourth. I also like horses #3, 8, and 10 as possible contenders for fourth place.

A $1 superfecta bet on this race is projected to pay over $20,000. So we’re going to use your free $10 to create 10 superfecta bets using these horses to increase our odds of hitting the jackpot!

This is what the bets look like – don’t worry, I’ll explain how to place them in a moment:

$1 Superfecta:
9 with 15, 16 with 15, 16, with 3, 6, 8, 10

$1 Superfecta:
15 with 9 with 16 with 6

$1 Superfecta:
16 with 9 with 15 with 6

If you were to go up to the window at Churchill Downs, you could say this to the teller and they would understand it perfectly and ask for $10 and give you your betting slips.

But, you can do this from the comfort of your home (legal in all states!) using DRF Bets. I’ll walk you through how to place these bets one by one.

Online HOrse Betting Walkthrough

Step 4: Click “$ Enter” and enter $1 as the wager amount.

Step 5: Select horse 9 for 1st place.

Step 6: Select horse 15 and 16 for 2nd place.

Step 7: Select horses 15 and 16 for 3rd place.

Step 8: Select horses 3,6,8, and 10 for 4th place.

Step 9: This should give you a total wager of $8, click place bet.

Congratulations, you’ve just placed your first exotic ticket! All this did was create a seperate superfecta bet for each possible combination of the selections we made, which is 8 total.

Step 10: Return to https://bets.drf.com/churchill-downs and select race 12.

Step 12: Click “$ Enter” and enter $1 as the wager amount.

Step 13: Select horse 15 for 1st, horse 9 for 2nd, horse 16 for 3rd, and horse 6 for fourth.

Step 14: Click Place bet.

We placed this bet in case #15 comes in first instead of #9, pushing #16 to third. If you’re keen to put some money up, go ahead and add 3,8 and 10 for fourth to increase your chances of winning.

Step 15: Return to https://bets.drf.com/churchill-downs and select race 12.

Step 16: Where it says “Select Wager Type”, choose “SPR”.

Step 17: Click “$ Enter” and enter $1 as the wager amount.

Step 18: Select horse 16  for 1st, horse 9 for 2nd, horse 15 for 3rd, and horse 6 for fourth.

Step 19: Click Place bet.

Like the previous bet, we’re creating this one as a contingency should #16 come in first, pushing #9 to second and #15 to third. We’d typically suggest keeping 3,8,10 as fourth place options, but that would go over our budget of $10.

All 10 of these bets are high risk, but we’re putting the odds in our favor both through sharp handicapping as well as sharp betting strategies.

Bonus $50 Strategy

The $10 winner could pay $300, the $1 exacta could pay $250, the $1 trifecta could pay $1600, and the superfecta as much as $20,000!

This slip pretty optimally combines the horses I feel are best to increase the odds of a winning bet paying out. If you want to bet more, I’d just increase the wager size proportionately across this strategy making your payout even bigger! 

Good luck!
